fields.Title: Effects of reactive oxygen species scavengers on the antibacterial action of zinc oxide
fields.Description/Abstract:
Metal oxide nanoparticles represent a class of cytotoxic materials with increasing
applications in biomedicine. Specifically, ZnO nanoparticles in the size range of 13 nm
have shown cytotoxic activity against bacteria of clinical relevance. The mechanism of
antibacterial action of these particles remains largely unknown. Here we report the
protective capacity of three anti-oxidants: superoxide dismutase, catalase, and
thiourea, against the cytotoxic effects of 13-nm ZnO nanoparticles on Staphylococcus
aureus and Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Both species were significantly protected by
superoxide dismutase and by catalase at lower ZnO concentrations, but not by
thiourea, suggesting that ZnO nanoparticles stimulate the production of specific
reactive oxygen species. To corroborate these results, we identified the stimulation of
reactive oxygen by ZnO nanoparticles using the molecular probe CM-H2DCFDA. We
further characterized the interaction of 13-nm ZnO nanoparticles with bacteria using
transmission electron microscopy coupled with Zn elemental mapping by energy
dispersive x-ray spectroscopy. Confocal microscopy was also performed after
exposure of bacteria that express red fluorescent protein in the periplasmic space to
ZnO nanoparticles. Results confirm that the cationic ZnO nanoparticles preferentially
associate with bacterial cells and stimulate membrane abnormalities. These studies
support the hypothesis that the stimulation of reactive oxygen species is a significant
contributor to the antibacterial activity of ZnO nanoparticles, and indicate a mechanism
of cell death by membrane disruption from reactive oxygen induction at the bacterial surface. 
This manuscript was submitted to the Journal of Nanoparticle Research in August 2011, and rejected in January of 2012. New data has been obtained and plans for resubmission by June 2013. 
Role:  Principal
